repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Emergency
            Education Reconstruction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project's overall outcome has
            been very satisfactory. The key lessons learned are: 1)
            Emergency projects should use a simple design as well as
            simplified procurement procedures. 2) Sector work should be
            undertaken and policy issues addressed during projects
            supervision using grant financing and through coordination
            with other donors. 3) Emergency projects should be designed
            in a modular nature, allowing for flexibility in
            re-allocating resources during implementation. 4) Qualified
            borrower personnel should be appointed full time to an
            implementation unit during the project preparation period
            and be given autonomy in the execution of the project. 5)
            Continuous technical assistance for implementation should be
            built into emergency projects from preparation through the
            first year of implementation. 6) The borrower's project
            unit should enjoy autonomy in its day-to-day operations. 7)
            Appointment of experienced Bank staff to field offices is
            the best way to ensure timely client service necessary for
            early project start-up, clearance of bidding documents, etc.
            8) Streamlined procurement guidelines are important
            ingredients for accelerated implementation of emergency
            projects. 9) Donor confidence in autonomous project
            management units should be strengthened through special
            procurement reviews as well as technical and financial
            audits. 10) Close communication and coordination among
            donors and nongovernmental organizations is important.

repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Emergency
            Education Reconstruction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The primary objective of the Emergency
            Education Reconstruction Project is to support Bosnia and
            Herzegovina's efforts to restore the delivery of
            primary education of acceptable quality during the 1996-97
            school year. A second objective is to help build capacity
            for planning and implementation of education programs at the
            state, entity, canton, and municipality level. To achieve
            these objectives under the prevailing constraints, the
            project focuses on meeting immediate educational needs in
            primary schooling which can, for the most part, be put in
            place prior to the start of the next school year in
            September, 1996. The components of the project are the
            following: 1) primary school reconstruction; 2) books and
            educational materials; 3) project implementation and
            capacity building; and 4) project preparation and pilot
            implementation in the Republica Srpska. They include civil
            works, provision of furniture and equipment and technical
            assistance and training.
